This holiday season, call, email, or video-chat with your family to cut back on waste, and reduce your impact on the planet!

This year for a Green Holiday gift, give an eerience that will last a lifetime and not end up in a landfill! Instead of giving merchandise, give tickets to a play, movie or sporting event or a gift certificate for dinner, a sports club membership or a spa treatment! The less material you buy the smaller your holiday carbon footprint will be.

This season go on the hunt for the perfect vintage one-of-a-kind-gift for your loved ones! Reduce your carbon footprint and buy second-hand toys, books, skis, and clothes to recycle old products and give them a new home.
Wrapping gifts in reusable materials, like comics, old maps, or magazines is fun, and saves you money. You can also cut up old holiday cards to make gift tags or decorations to hang.

link_name: Canada is taking serious action to fight climate change.
status_message_cleaned: Canada is taking serious action to fight climate change. Putting a price on carbon pollution is the most efficient way to reduce pollution and drive innovation. Just another way that we are leading in global climate action.

More waste is generated during the holiday season than any other time of the year. What will you do this year to reduce the amount of waste you produce? Here are some small things you can do daily to help reduce your impact on the environment:

Today is the winter solstice, which marks the shortest day of the year. To reduce your energy consumption plan a cozy evening with candles, bring out some board games, and enjoy well-deserved time with your family!

From wildfires in British Columbia to ice storms in Atlantic Canada, weather eerts at Environment and Climate Change Canada have drawn up their choice of the Top Weather Stories from across the country in . Extreme weather events like these demonstrate the effects of climate change, and remind us of the need to act now on climate both internationally and here at home.

Canadians had plenty of weather to talk about this year! Flooding caused significant damage in parts of Quebec and Ontario, while winter storms walloped Atlantic Canada. British Columbians faced the most destructive wildfire season in the province’s history, and record hot and dry conditions in the West also meant a year of distress for farmers and ranchers. From a list of significant weather events across Canada in , Environment and Climate Change Canada’s eerts have drawn up their choice of the Top Weather Stories from across the country. To know more:

link_name: The Government of Canada is taking action
status_message_cleaned: The Montreal Protocol is one of the most successful global agreements ever. Together with the world, Canada stopped the thinning of the ozone layer. And now, years later we are coming together under this agreement to stop climate change with the Kigali Amendment.

link_name: Photos from Environment and Climate Change's post
status_message_cleaned: Canada’s Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

Indigenous peoples from Canada, and around the world, are disproportionately affected by the impacts of climate change. At the same time, their knowledge, eeriences and innovations are vital when it comes to responding to climate impacts. This is why Canada has worked so hard to ensure that the voices of Indigenous peoples are heard — at home and abroad.
Today is Resilience Day at COP23. We are updating Canadian building codes and developing a retrofit code to adapt to climate change. Our goal is to create new clean buildings of the st century.

Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. SmartICE’s work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted.
Canada has an opportunity to be a leader in clean technology innovations. Canada's climate action plan will drive innovation and create clean-tech jobs.
Today is Gender Day at COP and Canada celebrates our powerful change agents: women and girls.

link_name: COP23 Day Two for Minister McKenna
status_message_cleaned: Watch today’s highlights from the Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna:

Today at COP23 in Bonn, Germany, Canada’s Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, co-chaired the Climate and Clean Air Coalition’s annual High Level Assembly. This meeting brought together countries that share the common goal of reducing pollutants that not only contribute to climate change, but also impact the air quality of millions of citizens around the world.

link_name: Photos from Environment and Climate Change's post
status_message_cleaned: Canada is taking an active and high profile approach, both domestically and internationally, to champion carbon pricing. Minister McKenna co-chaired with Feike Sijbesma, CEO of Royal DSM, the latest gathering of the Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition partnership of governments, businesses and other environmental stakeholders, showing the world the economic and environmental opportunities.

Today is Finance Day at COP23. Clean technology innovation is a core component of the Government of Canada’s Innovation and Skills Plan. In its most recent federal budget, the Government of Canada has pledged more than $2.3 billion to support clean tech growth across the country! Finance is a crucial aspect of growing green business.C

Today is Health Day at COP23. The Government of Canada is committed to reducing short-lived climate pollutants that are warming the planet and impacting our health, the quality of the air we breathe and the environment. By using clean technology to reduce short-lived climate pollutants, we will grow the economy and meet our climate change and air quality goals. Cleaner air leads to improved human health, including fewer asthma symptoms, a reduced risk of premature death and fewer heart related issues.

The fight against climate change is just as important at the local-level as it is on the international-level. At COP23, we celebrate local initiatives like the Halifax Solar City Program. Check it out!

Today is Industry Day at COP23. It reminds us that transitioning to cleaner sources of energy is not only good for the environment,but good for our economy too. More and more, renewable sources of energy are becoming cost competitive with traditional sources. We know there are over $20 trillion in new opportunities for investments in emerging markets between now and . Canadian businesses are well-positioned to seize the opportunities that clean growth presents; resulting in new jobs, new technologies and less pollution. The Government of Canada is investing strategically to support growth across all sectors of the economy.

Today is Forests Day at COP . Did you know forests absorb and store carbon? These “carbon sinks” actually remove carbon from the atmosphere. Under the Pan-Canadian Framework, the Government of Canada will support efforts to enhance carbon stored in our forests, wetlands and agricultural soils.
Today is Transport Day at COP23. Here at home, Canada is committed to investing in active transportation projects which will keep our communities healthy and clean.

Today is Oceans and Coastal Zones Day at COP23. The Government of Canada recognizes the enormous potential for business development and job creation in the global marine renewable energy market which is projected at $900 billion by .

link_name: The Government of Canada is taking action
status_message_cleaned: Today is Human Settlements [AKA Cities] Day at COP23. In Canada, about % of national greenhouse gas emissions come from heating and cooling homes and buildings. If we want to leave a cleaner planet, cities must adapt to deal with climate change. To address this issue, Canada is investing in climate-resilient infrastructure and standards. Learn more about sustainable and efficient homes and buildings:

At COP23, Canada remains committed to making investments in water and wastewater utilities for sustainable communities. Canada is home to roughly % of the world’s renewable freshwater supply. We are working hard to protect it for Canadians. For more information on Canada’s efforts to protect freshwater, visit:
To effectively tackle climate change, governments and the financial community must finance climate action on a massive scale and at unprecedented speed.

Taking part in COP is Enerkem, a Canadian sustainable business that produces clean fuels and green chemicals from waste. Using clean technology they convert waste into clean fuels at the world’s first commercial waste-to-biofuels facility in Edmonton, Alberta. Enerkem is also developing other exciting biorefinery projects here in Canada, as well as in the USA and in Europe.
